official-title.#text: To provide for a Medicare primary care graduate medical education pilot project in order to improve access to the primary care workforce.

committee-name.#tail: , and in addition to the Committee on
, for a period to be subsequently determined by the Speaker, in each case for consideration of such provisions as fall within the jurisdiction of the committee concerned

cosponsor.#tail: ) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the

short-title.#text: Primary Care Workforce Access Improvement Act of 2013

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

header.#text: Medicare primary care graduate medical education pilot project

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: (in this section referred to as the
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Secretary of Health and Human Services

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , in accordance with the provisions of this section, to test models for providing payment under such title for direct graduate medical education and indirect medical education to medical education entities, which entities are not otherwise eligible to receive such payments under the Medicare program, for the costs of training primary care residents.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: title XVIII of the Social Security Act

quote.#tail: ) shall conduct a pilot project under the Medicare program under

text.#text: The

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall conduct the pilot project under this section over a 5-year period, which shall begin not later than 180 days after the date of the enactment of this Act.

text.#text: The

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall test two of each of the following models:

text.#text: Under the pilot project, the

A model in which the medical education entity receiving funds under the pilot project is a community-based independent corporate entity collaborating with two or more hospitals to operate one or more primary care graduate medical residency training programs.
A model in which—
the medical education entity receiving funds under the pilot project is established by two or more hospitals to operate one or more primary care graduate medical residency training programs; and
such hospitals may be the sole corporate members of the entity but the governing board of the entity shall include at least one community representative.

A model in which the medical education entity receiving funds under the pilot project is a hospital subsidiary or independent corporation that operates one or more primary care graduate medical residency training programs for a hospital with community participation in the governance of the subsidiary or corporation.
A model in which—

the medical education entity receiving funds under the pilot project is independent of any hospital but collaborates with a hospital in operating one or more primary care graduate medical residency training programs; and
the medical education entity may include a university or school of medicine.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: may test models of medical education entities in addition to those described in

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Primary Care Workforce Access Improvement Act of 2013/s:2/ss:c/p:1

text.#text: Under the pilot project, the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: may give priority to testing models that demonstrate the capability of improving the quality, quantity, and distribution of primary care physicians, including the ability to enhance primary care delivery in rural and underserved areas.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Secretary of Health and Human Services

text.#text: Under the pilot project, the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall establish a process under which payments are made to each medical education entity participating under such project for direct graduate medical education and indirect medical education costs with respect to primary care residents enrolled under a primary care graduate medical residency training program operated pursuant to a model of such entity under
instead of any payment or adjustment that would otherwise be made to a participant hospital (as defined in
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Primary Care Workforce Access Improvement Act of 2013/s:2/ss:c

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: ) of such entity for indirect and direct graduate medical education costs under
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Primary Care Workforce Access Improvement Act of 2013/s:2/ss:m

text.#text: Under the pilot project, the

text.#text: Payments to a medical education entity under the pilot project, with respect to a primary care graduate medical education residency program, for a cost reporting period during which the entity is participating in such pilot shall be, based on the most recently available data with respect to a previous cost reporting period, equal to the sum of the following:
The amount that, out of all of the payment amounts (determined on a per resident basis) received by hospitals under

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: for such previous cost reporting period, is equal to the 95th percentile of such payment amounts.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: section 1886(h) of the Social Security Act

text.#text: The amount that, out of all of the additional payment amounts (determined on a per resident basis) received by hospitals under

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: for such previous cost reporting period, is equal to the 95th percentile of such payment amounts.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: section 1886(d)(5)(B) of the Social Security Act

header.#text: Additional payments for programs serving underserved areas

text.#text: In providing for such payments under this subsection to medical education entities, the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: and the Federal Supplementary Medical Insurance Trust Fund under

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: section 1817 of the Social Security Act

and
, respectively, of

text.#text: A medical education entity receiving payments under the pilot project shall use such payments for the training of primary care residents, including training activities in appropriate inpatient and outpatient settings in primary care graduate medical residency training programs accredited by the Accreditation Council for Graduate Medical Education or the American Osteopathic Association and for all relevant topics including patient care, care management, working in teams, supervision, and quality improvement.

Payments shall only be made for training primary care residents up to the initial board certification of such residents, except that with respect to training in geriatric medicine, payments may also be made for a fellowship after initial board certification.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: ) during the duration of the participation of such entity in such project.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Primary Care Workforce Access Improvement Act of 2013/s:2/ss:e/p:1

text.#text: A medical education entity receiving funds under the pilot project, with respect to a primary care graduate medical residency training program, shall be allowed to increase by up to 50 percent the number of full-time equivalent primary care residents enrolled in the such program (determined in accordance with the process under

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: and
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Primary Care Workforce Access Improvement Act of 2013/s:2/ss:h/p:2

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , any participant hospital of a medical education entity under the pilot project, shall receive payments under

header.#text: Exception to ensure residents enrolled during pilot are able to complete training

text.#text: In no case may the total duration of the pilot project exceed seven years and in no case may payments be made under this section to a medical education entity for a period exceeding seven years.

text.#text: The

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: is authorized to enter into an agreement with the Institute of Medicine to conduct a study on the results of the pilot project. Such agreement shall provide for the Institute of Medicine to submit, not later than 1 year after the completion of the pilot project under this section (or, if sooner, January 1, 2021), to Congress a report on the results of such study, including—

text.#text: The

a detailed analysis of the effects of the pilot, including the quality, quantity, and distribution of primary care physicians during and after the pilot project compared to the quality, quantity, and distribution of such physicians before the pilot project; and the governance, administration and financial strength of the medical educational entities that participated in the pilot project;
recommendations on the extent to which the pilot project should be expanded to all primary care residents; and
recommendations for such legislation and administrative actions as needed.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: determines that any of the models tested under the pilot project under this section enhance the quality, quantity, and distribution of primary care physicians for Medicare beneficiaries, the
may initiate comparable primary care training projects.

header.#text: Primary care graduate medical residency training program

term.#tail: means a resident enrolled in an approved medical residency training program in family medicine, general internal medicine, general pediatrics, or geriatric medicine.
